skill.name: Backend Models
skill.description: Define database models and ORM entities with proper naming, relationships, validation, and data integrity constraints. Use this skill when creating or modifying model classes, database table definitions, model relationships (one-to-many, many-to-many), data validation rules, database constraints, or model methods. Apply when working with ORM model files, ActiveRecord, SQLAlchemy, Sequelize, Prisma schemas, or any database model definitions that map objects to database tables and enforce data structure and relationships.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure prompt-based skill containing only markdown documentation. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or file system access beyond its own content. The skill provides guidance instructions for writing database models.

content.user_title: Design Database Models and ORM Entities
content.value_statement: Database models often lack proper validation and relationships. This skill provides clear guidance for defining database models with proper naming conventions, relationships, constraints, and data integrity rules.
actual_capabilities: Define database models with proper naming conventions
Add validation rules and database constraints
Set up foreign keys and cascade behaviors
limitations: Does not generate actual code files
Does not connect to databases or run migrations
Only provides guidance, not automated implementation

use_cases.title: Create ORM Entities
use_cases.description: Define database models using SQLAlchemy, Sequelize, Prisma, or ActiveRecord with proper relationships and validation.

use_cases.title: Design Data Schema
use_cases.description: Set up database tables with foreign keys, indexes, constraints, and data types for web applications.

use_cases.title: Enforce Data Integrity
use_cases.description: Implement cascade behaviors, unique constraints, and validation rules to maintain data quality.

prompt_templates.title: Create User Model
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a user model with email, password_hash, and name fields. Add email uniqueness validation and required password field.

prompt_templates.title: Define Post Relationship
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a post model that belongs to a user. Set up the relationship on both sides with proper foreign keys.

prompt_templates.title: Many-to-Many Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a many-to-many relationship between posts and tags using a join table with cascade delete.

prompt_templates.title: Add Model Scopes
prompt_templates.prompt: Add scopes to the article model for published articles and articles by specific authors.

output_examples.input: Create a Product model with name, price, and category. Products belong to a category. Categories have many products.
output: Define Product model with name (string, required), price (decimal, required), category_id (foreign key)
Add Category model with name field
Add database constraint for positive price values

best_practices: Use explicit foreign key names that indicate both the table and column
Add database-level constraints alongside application validation
Set up indexes on fields frequently used in WHERE clauses and JOINs
anti_patterns: Using vague field names like 'data' or 'info' instead of specific names
Skipping foreign key constraints for convenience
Omitting created_at and updated_at timestamps on audit-relevant models

faq.question: Which ORMs does this skill support?
faq.answer: SQLAlchemy, Sequelize, Prisma, ActiveRecord, and other major ORM frameworks.

faq.question: Does this skill create actual database tables?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance for writing model code. You run migrations separately.

faq.question: Can it help with complex many-to-many relationships?
faq.answer: Yes. It provides guidance on setting up join tables with proper cascade behaviors.

faq.question: Does it validate existing database connections?
faq.answer: No. The skill only provides coding guidance, not runtime database operations.

faq.question: Can it help with migration file generation?
faq.answer: It can guide you on writing model definitions. Actual migration tools are separate.

faq.question: Does it work with both SQL and NoSQL databases?
faq.answer: Yes. It covers relational models and can guide NoSQL document structures.
